title: volunteers-helping-throughout-musselburgh
story: The emergency efforts are being co-ordinated by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership as they do what they can to support the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall, which have a combined population of about ,.They are working from the Resilient Musselburgh Hub, which is based at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoThe support to Resilient Musselburgh from community volunteers has been fantastic and has allowed us to deliver much-needed support to those who need it most.ldquoOur volunteers have been deployed every day and are providing a much-needed and crucial service.ldquoWe now have  amazing volunteers registered and they have been deployed on a daily basis to assist in delivering lunches to the vulnerable, emergency food supplies, prescriptions and leafleting targeted areas of the community.ldquoVolunteers are contacted as available and attend at the hub, where their delivery is brought out to them."ldquoThey have also been attending ious chemists to uplt and deliver prescriptions.ldquoThey must be on the Resilient Musselburgh register to be deployed as this provides public liability insurance cover.ldquoWe have funded the emergency food provision through the purchase of supplies which have been made into emergency packs which include food and items for personal hygiene. We also maintain a stock of sanitary products and hearing aid batteries.ldquoDuring the weekend period, when the hub is not open, a quantity of emergency food provision is relocated to allow provision over the weekendurgently required.The team has delivered  five-day lunch packs to families in the community, and volunteers in Whitecraig have also distributed  meals, supplied by local restaurant the Mercat Grill.Mr Clark said: ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership has been allocated pound, by East Lothian Council from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund.ldquoWe are working with Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council to focus these new funds to provide the most positive impact we can to those who need our support. We are also supporting Wallyford and Whitecraig Community Councils as we look towards a co-ordinated effort during these very dficult times for many.Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council has allocated pound, and a further pound has been donated by Wallyford Community Council to help fund the initiative.Mr Clark said: ldquoWe are currently managing all the calls that come via our dedicated number, co-ordinating the registration and deployment of all volunteers and maintaining an action database of all requirements to ensure a log of what needs done and when it has been completed.ldquoIn addition, we are dealing with all the elements of the referral forms from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre that require action from Resilient Musselburgh. Given the current social distancing requirements, the co-ordination is being undertaken remotely via shared online access.ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, soyou know of anyone who would be interested in supporting us then they can register using the following link and scrolling down to Resilient Musselburgh Covid-: eastlothian.gov.uk musselburghapAlister Hadden, chair of Wallyford Community Council, and Shona Bennett, chair of Whitecraig Community Council, highlighted the teamrsquos ldquoamazing volunteers, saying they had nothing but ldquoadmiration and praise for them.The hub has priority access to Tesco Musselburgh to buy emergency food supplies when necessary.Tesco has donated pound in vouchers and provides a free weekly supply of fresh fruit to support lunch provision for vulnerable people.Resilient Musselburgh has been nominated by the Pinkie Farm Shop for a pound grant from its charity MADL .For help contact the Community Resilience phone line:  .

title: let-us-race-pleads-racecourse-boss
story: Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth says the only way to save the sport is to allow racing to resume.Racing across the United kingdom has been suspended since March .However during a video conference meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee, which oversees the East Lothian course, Mr Fanrsworth warned that only theof racing itself will save it for the future.He said: "The only thing that will save us is getting us racing again."Racing needs to get racing again, it will be behind closed doors but racing is unique because that is viable because of the digital s which allow us to show races and betting to operate online."Mr Farnsworth told the committee it was nearly impossible to predict the impact of the racing closures on Musselburgh.He said staff at the course have been furloughed, but they were lobbying to find a way to hold races behind closed doors as early as June or July.And he said the Racecourse Associationhas been urging the Horse Betting Levy Board to release some of an estimated poundmillion it has in its reserves to pay courses abandonment payments to help them weather the storm.He said: "We believe the Levy Board should be paying racecourses an abadonment payment. In recent years that payment responsibility was taken up by Media Rights but the Levy Board is sitting on poundmillion so they should use some of that."Musselburgh ward councillor Stuart Currie, who sits on the committee, described the claims the Levy Board, which is a non departmental Government body, had so much money in reserves as "outrageous".He said: "The British Horseracing Authority needs to step up and step out and get some of that cash out to the industry."It is outrageouspeople are potentially going to the wall."

title: pink-door-gets-green-light
story: The stunned home owner was ordered to make a retrospective planning application by East Lothian Council planners after they were alerted to the change in the conservation area.A single complainer lodged an objection to the colour of the door, telling planners it was ldquotoo bright and not in keeping with other doors on the street.However the applicant highlighted other doors in her street which are painted red, yellow and blue in her defence of the decision.And planning officers received letters supporting her decision to paint the door which is not visible from the street.Granting permission for the pink door to remain, the planning officer said: ldquoThe door, whilst visible from a neighbouring first floor flat, is only visible in short duration glimpsed views from the public road.ldquoIn those short duration glimpsed views, the door, whilst painted pink, is not so discernibly from public places that it detracts from or be seen tobe harmful to the character and appearance of the conservation area.ldquoNor is it seen to be at odds with the colour of other doors of neighbouring residential properties.Applying for planning permission for the paintwork, which is described as coral, the home owner said: ldquoI had no idea that I needed planning permission for this and assumed it would be okay as there are many other strong coloured front doors in our local streets.ldquoOur door was chipped and neglected and I was aimingto make it appear smarter ndash it very much ties in with my design aesthetic and these colourful front doors are becoming increasingly popular in both conservation areas and outwith.She pointed out that the front door of her house, on Dirleton Avenue, was not visible from the street because of high hedges and its corner location.She added: ldquoWe invested considerable money in upgrading the front door and the gilded lettering and have received many compliments.

story: Heres what you need to know.Contact free deliveryA spokesman for the Royal Mail said: "The initiative is a simple way for the public to say thanks and stay connected with their local postmen and women, while respecting the Governmentrsquos social distancing rules."Giving a thumbs up is also a handy reminder not to reach out to try and take parcels direct from postmen and women to ensure contact free delivery."Royal Mailrsquos postmen and postwomen are at the heart of the communities in which they work. title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. title: unremembered-scotland-new-book-reveals-fascinating-snippets-nations-history
story: Getting there had involved overcoming the forces of nature, biding time for tides and the weather to align in an act of grace that would allow a small craft to be hauled on to the narrow, shingle beach.Patience was rewarded. As Patrick Baker paddled his kayak past wobbling purple and white jellyfish and the occasional porpoise, battling to beat the temperamental currents, the deserted island of Belnahua took shape.Once ashore, he trekked over the beach and the overgrown grass to reach deserted terraced homes where dozens of slate quarry workers and their families once lived. Long since abandoned, the dilapidated walls and rusting machinery remain rooted, crumbling monuments to an almost forgotten age when Scottish island mined slate put a roof over the world.ldquoBelnahua was very ghostly, says Baker, an Edinburgh-based outdoor writer whose new book The Unremembered Placesexplores some of Scotlandrsquos wild, often overlooked locations and unravels the fascinating stories embedded in their past.ldquoIt was eerie and poignant and beautul, he continues. ldquoThe journey to Belnahua adds to its mystique. The island has that rare frozen-in-time quality to it.ldquoLots of the places I ended up visiting had that same feeling.Part travelogue and part social history, Baker has recorded his journeys to locations that have fallen off the beaten track: hidden caves, a quiet Highland reservoir with a deadly human toll linked to its construction, and secluded islands.Despite doing the footwork to become familiar with each before setting off, often these "unremembered" places still managed to capture Baker off-guard either by their enigmatic beauty or a tiny detail that shed new light on their seldom-told histories.At Belnahua, once at the epicentre of a mammoth slate industry which saw it and its neighbouring islands send Dalradian slate around the world, Baker picked his way through the "ghost village" with its abandoned homes, corroded machinery, rusted steam-driven crane and flooded quarries.Beyond the physical remains, he unravelled a much deeper story of island communities surrounded by turbulent waters which carried an astonishing number of vessels ndash a fair number of which would end up wrecked as they battled against the harsh, stormy Atlantic waters.ldquoThat brutality of the winter storms and their location on the edge of the Atlantic, would have made it an incredible place to live, says Baker. ldquoAt one point the water around Belnahua was one of the busiest watercourses around the UK, which is incredible to think of.A series of economic and natural calamities including a storm which Baker describes as being ldquoof epic proportions devastated the industry, leaving ft deep mines flooded by the swell of seawater which drenched their workings, and families with no work or reason to stay.Once home to more than  people at the slate industryrsquos peak at the end of the th century, by the s the island was empty.ldquoIt feels like it has been deserted, reflects Baker, whose book links the growth of the slate industry with bustling sea traffic and the rise of lighthouses to guide vessels on their way.ldquoIt was a rapid turnaround of being a very populated island with many people living on a tiny patch of land, to being completely deserted within a matter of weeks.ldquoIt has a feeling of rapid desertion to it. Itrsquos quite eerie but fascinating with machinery lying where it was left and no-one going to remove it.ldquoThe houses are there, he adds. ldquoBut what struck me was the row of deserted cottages which housed the slate miners and their families.ldquoIt banks to a small beach that is just footsteps from the front door to the water. I stood there and thought what an incredible place to live, but equally what a very hard and brutal place.ldquoItrsquos only really when you visit these places that you can transpose yourself into what it must have been like to live there and experience that.ldquoAnd Belnhua is very visceral and very real.While some "unremembered" spots are remote and challenging to reach, such as Blackwater Reservoir in Lochaber where he was taken aback by the small graveyard and the human cost of creating the dam, others are far closer to urban le.The Glen Loin Caves near Arrochar in West Dunbartonshire are the reputed resting point for Robert the Bruce and his army after the Battle of Methven in . However, Baker points out that much more recently they were a focal point for working-class sporting prowess.For two decades from the s, groups from the hard-working shipyards and poverty-stricken Glasgow tenements made the area their playground, taking up weekend residence in the caves from where they would climb the rocky walls of the "Arrochar Alps".The climbing clubs they formed would go on to lay the foundations for the sportrsquos modern standards, techniques and ethics.However, as years passed, the location of the caves they frequented became largely forgotten Bakerrsquos search for them resulting in a frustrating challenge over jagged rocks, through pines and across overgrown gashes in the hillside before finally stumbling into the dark, gaping entrance.ldquoSome of the places are pretty remote and hard to get to which may be a discouragement to people seeking to visit them, says Baker, as he explains the balance to be struck between drawing attention to secluded, forgotten spots and attracting people to visit.ldquoWe want to share the wonderment we are seeing and share these stories, he adds, ldquobut we donrsquot want to degrade the places or their mystery.Thatrsquos a particular issue for the "wild" islands he visits, dotted across Loch Awe and Loch Shiel, havens for wildle, some harbouring centuries-old graveyards or, in the case of Eilean Fhianain, once home to Irish missionary Saint Finnan and with its ruined chapel and burial grounds.Other islands revealed another side to their previously well-documented character.Baker explored Inchkeith Island, three miles north of Edinburgh in the Firth of Forth, aware of its prominence as a stop-off point for vessels between Fe and Edinburgh since the th century but surprised to discover its links to a bizarre attempt to invade the Port of Leith.ldquoI often had an idea about the story that was going to unravel in a particular place, and then found out other elements, says Baker, whose book covers eight destinations, each with its own character and signicance.ldquoIt was fascinating to find out about Inchkeithrsquos strategic importance and how, in , it was used as a sort of staging post for a fleet under the command of Scots-born John Paul Jones, who effectively founded the US Navy.A squadron of five ships had gathered at the mouth of the estuary near Dunbar, sparking panic in towns along the coast.Sailing under a commission for the Continental Navy for the American Colonies, John Paul Jones was known for attacking British naval and merchant ships and launching land offensives.His sights on this occasion, writes Baker, were set on Leith.Having penned a letter threatening to attack the port, his vessels took anchor at Inchkeith Island to await their next move.As luck had it, a fierce westerly gale put paid to Jonesrsquos plans. Having been prevented from reaching the port, Jones decided it was ldquoimpossible to pursue the enterprise with a good prospect of success.Baker, who has previously written about stories and landscape of the Cairngorms, says while the "unremembered" locations explored in his book may seem disparate, they share common links.ldquoScotlandrsquos wild histories ... speak of immeasurable social change, of the movement of people through time and landscape, he writes. ldquoYet they are often lost, overlooked or passed by.ldquoThey still have cultural relevance, but we donrsquot tend to give them enough signicance. Thatrsquos the common theme.The Unremembered Places by Patrick Baker is published by Birlinn on May

title: carina-contini-three-great-recipes-approaching-summer
story: A TINY part of me has to admit that deep down the lockdown has felt like getting a day off school when I was eight years old due to the February snowfalls. My more conscious awareness is of a fear for an unknown future, but like everything in le we must all try and make the best of the situation we are presented with.Lets take this time and savour it. It may be the only time we have with our families ndash , like me, you have your three children at home before two of them are hopefully able to start their next adventure at colleges across the country.We traded our city home in Edinburgh for a one in the country about nine years ago. The one-hour long commute is torture during normal times, but being here today it feels like a little bit of heaven.Our kitchen garden, normally only for the restaurant, is providing deliveries for our community and a little salad for ourselves. The weather has been so good Irsquove even been helping my husband Victor with the planting. Up until now Irsquove been a fair-weather harvester only.Soyou can, enjoy the outside space you have. Make the most of it as the warmer weather approaches. If you donrsquot have a garden as I know many wonrsquot, enjoy a Pimmrsquos with the window open. It will be much better for your knees, I can assure you.Carina Contini is owner of Contini George Street, Edinburgh Cannonball Restaurant  Bar, Castle Hill, Edinburgh and The Scottish Cafe  Restaurant ndash located at the gardens entrance of the Scottish National Gallery, EdinburghThree great recipes to get you in the mood for summerClassic Pimmrsquos  LemonadeI know itrsquos not Scottish. Itrsquos not even Italian. But itrsquos delicious and it feels fun when served in a big pitcher and you can feel the sun on your face.Ingredientsbull ml Pimmrsquos No bull  litre lemonadebull  cucumberbull  sprigs of fresh mint, washedbull  orange, cut into slicesbull  strawberries, washedbull  ice cubesMethod Yoursquoll need a large jug to make the punch. Leave the bottle of Pimmrsquos and lemonade in the fridge overnight as it keeps the drink colder. Wash the cucumber and slice into diagonal strips about mm thick. When they are this shape itrsquos easy to pick them up and eat them. Add the cucumber, mint, orange and ice to the jug. Add the Pimmrsquos and top up with lemonade. Decorate with the strawberries and relax.Chilli BBQ ChickenThis recipe can be cooked in the oven or on a BBQ.Serves Ingredientsbull  green chillies, seeds removed and finely choppedbull  cloves of garlic, peeledbull  whole unwaxed lemon or  preserved lemon, pips removedbull  tbsp extra virgin olive oilbull Generous pinch of saltbull Large handful of fresh parsley, leaves onlybull Large handful of fresh coriander, leaves onlybull .kg lb oz free-range or organic chicken, backbone removed and squashed flat and lay skin side up on a roasting trayMethod Cut the lemon in half and remove any seeds. Mix all of the ingredients in the blender or food processor until smooth. Pour this mixture over the chicken and gently rub in. Leave to marinade for at least an hour. Sprinkle some more salt over the chicken and a generous amount of extra virgin olive oil. Roast at degC degF Gas  for  minutes so the skin becomes lovely and tasty then lower the oven to degC degF Gas  and cook for another  minutes or so until the leg of the chicken easily removes from the carcass.Strawberry PavlovaWith the first of the Scottish strawberries hitting the shops this is the perfect dessert.Serves Ingredientsbull g free range egg whites bull g caster sugarbull A pinch of saltbull  heaped tsp cornflourbull  tsp vanilla extractbull  tsp white wine vinegarbull  x g punnets of fresh strawberries, stalks removed and cut into quartersbull  x g punnet of fresh raspberriesbull g icing sugarbull ml of double creamMethod Preheat your oven to degC degF Gas  Carefully separate the egg whites and beat with the pinch of sugar until very stf. Very slowly beat in the caster sugar. I do this one teaspoon at a time to ensure the air stays in the mixture. When all the sugar has been added, mix the vanilla, vinegar and cornflour and then beat into the meringue. Rather than using a baking sheet lined with parchment I use a ceramic pie dishand oil very lightly. I serve the pavlova in this dish so it looks pretty and stops the chances of the meringue breaking. Fill the dish with thick scoops of the mixture to form the pavlova shape and bake in a preheated oven for  minutes then turn off the oven and leave for a further  minutes. Remove the dish from the oven and allow to cool. Meanwhile heat one punnet of raspberries with the icing sugar in a pan until the raspberries start to pop and the sugar has dissolved. Cook for about  or  minutes, stirring to ensure the mixture doesnt burn. Cool and then sieve the seeds to make a coulis and add the strawberries to the coulis. Whip the double cream until soft peaks form and then spoon the cream onto the pavlova and then dress with the strawberry mixture.

title: preview-virtual-whisky-tasting-adelphi-royal-mile-whiskies
story: For people like me, springtime means only one thing ndash whisky.This is festival season, when companies showcase their new expressions and fans get together to share stories, impressions of the new drams and generally have a rip-roaring time.But this year, just like almost everything  in the world right now, that alternative festive season has been shut down ndash forcing many companies to reach out to people online, with virtual festivals, digital tastings and the like.Irsquove joined in one so far, which was a great laugh, but, to be honest, I did miss finding those gems you run into at a real festival ndash the rare expressions from under the counter, or the special releases from one of the great independent bottlers.And thatrsquos why next weekend is going to be such a treat for whisky fans. This coming Friday, at .pm on the dot, around  fans from all over the world will be logging in to join a virtual tasting by one of the greatest bottlers of them all ndash Adelphi.If you know whisky, that one world will have made you stop and take notice. If you donrsquot let me explain. Adelphi is like the Linn of hi-fi, the Aston Martin of motoring, the Gleneagles of hotels ndash basically,you see anything with that name on a bottle, you know yoursquore in for a serious treat.So why does a company like this need to get involved in virtual tastings  Surely they donrsquot need the money, or the publicity  Connal Mackenzie, group sales manager with the company, says the reason theyrsquore doing it is much more basic than that.ldquoThis is the only way we can get out to the Adelphi people, he says. ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for this virus, wersquod be gearing up for festivals.ldquoWe were going to be launching a new whisky list anyway, and we usually try to fall in to some kind of festival to do that, get feedback them and pour some drams for people.ldquoWe wanted to bottle up some samples and get them to the people who are missing out on festivals around the UK and further afield. This was the ideal  to do that.Interest in everything that Adelphi produces is usually huge, and new bottlings usually sell out very quickly, so it came as no surprise to me when Mackenzie told me that when the event was publicised, the tasting packs ndash five new expressions that will be tasted during Fridayrsquos session ndash sold out within  hours, with interest from as far afield as Australia and America.Mackenzie will be conducting the tasting, alongside Alex Bruce, managing director of Adelphi, and Arthur Motley, of Royal Mile Whiskies, which sells Adelphi whisky and has worked closely with them on Fridayrsquos event.But he is at pains to stress that the tasting is no exclusive event. ldquoA total of  people will have a tasting pack ndash however, this is not just for those people. Yes, the tasting pack will be part of the discussion, but there will be plenty of people around the world who have bottles of Adelphi open ndash or any whisky for that matter ndash and we want them to join us.ldquoAlex, Arthur and myself will be just having a general chat about whisky ndash yes, the focus will be on our whiskies ndash but we want to invite anyone whorsquos a fan to open a bottle and join us.So, to the critical question ndash whatrsquos going to be on show  Irsquom speaking to Mackenzie by phone, but I can almost see the glint of excitement in his eyes. ldquoWersquore pretty pleased with this list ndash and we hope the people who join us will be too hellipSo here are the drams:bull Ardnamurchan   Year Old Single Cask .% not- this is a bottling from Adelphirsquos own distillery, and the first taste of the actual whisky ahead of an release hopefully later this year.bull The Glover  Year Old Batch  .% not- a special mix of Ardnamurchan and whisky from the legendary Chichibu Distillery in Japan.bull Linkwood   Year Old Single Cask .%bull Caol Ila   Year Old Single Cask .%And just for a special treat:bull Bas Armagnac   Year Old Armagnac Single Cask .%So, how can I get involved, I ask Connal. ldquoWell, he said, ldquoeven though all our tasting packs have sold out, donrsquot let that bother you. Just log on to one of our social media channels, open your favourite dram and join the discussion.Irsquom not sure I can think of a better way to spend a Friday night!If you want to join in, go to one of the following at .pm on Friday, April :https:www.facebook adelphihttps:www.instagram adelphi https:www.youtube channel UCHWysRZyIuYotSvy-KQ

title: westminster-must-seize-opportunity-to-drag-present--says-snp-mps-prepare-first-digital-pmqs
story: Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, will be at the Commons dispatch box, standing in for the recuperating Boris Johnson, and will face Sir Keir Starmer, who will attend his first PMQs as Labour leader.MPs yesterday backed a motion to enable them to contribute to certain parliamentary proceedings via the Zoom video-conferencing system in light of the restrictions imposed by the coronavirus outbreak.Up to  MPs will from today be allowed in the Commons chamber with up to a further  contributing remotely to departmental questions, urgent questions and ministerial statements in what has been described as a ldquohybrid Parliament.Kirsty Blackman, the SNP deputy leader, said the UK Parliament must seize the opportunity of change to modernise the democratic process, declaring: ldquoThe first ever virtual PMQs should be a catalyst for real change and provide a moment of signicant realisation for the UK Government.ldquoThe House of Commons has never been keen to endear itself as a parliament fit for the st century but these vital changes in light of the coronavirus crisis highlight the opportunity for Westminster to drag itself into the present day.ldquoIf we want to be able to make political le - elected office or those working behind the scenes - accessible for all, we have to lead by example. Itrsquos time for Westminster to wake up to the huge potential that these changes unleash and commit to reforming the Commons for good, she added.As a small number of MPs debated the motion the chamber had black and yellow taping on the floor and seats were marked with a no-entry sign or a tick to show where they could sit, ensuring they kept to the two-metre social distancing rule.Jacob Rees-Mogg, the Commons Leader, told MPs said the new digital Parliament might not be perfect and technical glitches were likely to occur but he insisted: ldquoWe must not let the perfect be the enemy of the good."Mr Rees-Mogg explained that he expected to bring forward further motions shortly so MPs could extend the virtual ways of working for a longer period and to ldquomore substantive business including legislation.Karen Bradley, who chairs the Commons Procedure Committee, pointed out it had not looked thoroughly at remote voting, noting how ldquosome others have tried the trial run of it and cant say it was absolutely brilliant. A lot more work will need to be done".Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle pointed out no decision had yet been taken with regards to voting and that any considerations to do so would be ldquocompletely checked" before being implemented.In exchanges, Labourrsquos John Spellar said the Commons had to be the "epicentre of the democratic system" and its role scaled-up in the coming weeks to ensure questions are answered by ministers, noting: "Otherwise, what is the point of Parliament "Tory backbencher Sir Desmond Swayne, commenting on the limiting of numbers in the chamber, claimed it would be "outrageous"MPs were excluded from debates."This is the precedent that were now setting and it would be outrageousmembers elected to this House were unable to come and bring their concerns to this chamber because there were already a sufficient number of members within it," he said.Meanwhile, the House of Lords held its first-ever virtual sitting.Instead of a packed chamber for question time, peers took part remotely from their homes by internet link.The historic change led to less rowdy exchanges as members were called inidually by the Lord Speaker, Lord Fowler, to speak rather than having to bob up and down in their seats in the House.Earlier in the Commons, Mr Rees-Mogg raised a smile among MPs when he joked: "In , when the Black Death affected this country, Parliament couldnt sit and didnt the session was cancelled.ldquoThanks to modern technology, even I have moved on from  and Im glad to say that we can sit to carry out these fundamental constitutional s. And Im enormously grateful to many who are just as traditionalist as I am, who have accepted these constraints."

title: issue-day-mafia
story: Italy has been crippled by the virus With more than , confirmed cases and , deaths, Italy has been the worst affected country in Europe. Its health service has been brought to its knees and the country remains under strict lockdown.So how can the Mafia thrive Rather than impinging their activities, lsquoLa Cosa Nostrarsquo - as the mob refers to itself - is defying lockdown and capitalising on the vulnerability of iniduals and businesses.In what ways Earlier this month, members held an elaborate funeral procession for a -year-old scion of one of Sicilys most renowned mob families, despite lockdown meaning funerals have been banned since early March. In the Sicilian district of Palermo, a local mob boss also organised a Good Friday church service, but it was ultimately halted by police.Making money Mafia clans are offering credit to firms on the brink, with anti-Mafia body, SOS Impresa, saying the virus has essentially transformed the mob into Italyrsquos largest bank, even buying shares in at-risk firms to offer apparent lsquolelinesrsquo that could soon be dead-weights.Targeting the vulnerable The Mafia provide necessities to poverty-stricken neighbourhoods - but these residents are then in the mobrsquos debt. Some debts are being repaid by those who find themselves newly unemployed agreeing to become foot-soldiers, boosting the Mafiarsquos numbers.Cleaning The mob has always invested in cleaning firms and delivery services and are now focusing on running funeral homes and hospital laundry services, two areas under severe pressure presently.Itrsquos always been this way On the island of Sicily, which was ruled by foreign invaders for centuries, islanders banded together to protect themselves and carry out their own brand of justice. In fact, the term rsquoMafioisorsquo - or lsquoMafia memberrsquo - originally had no criminal connotations, meaning only someone who was suspicious of authority.But by the mid-th century, the groups became private armies - lsquoMafiersquo - who extorted landowners and firms for protection money, evolving into the Sicilian Mafia as we know it today.The American mob A separate entity to the Sicilian Mafia, the US Mafia follows the same code of conduct, but is not faring so well. The cancellation of sporting events has wiped out millions of dollars in illegal gambling earnings, while other mafia mainstays, including extorting restaurants and construction rackets, have also ended, with eateries closed and building projects halted.Itrsquos just like the movies So many classic films feature the Mafia, from Francis Ford Coppolarsquos The Godfather, starring Marlon Brando, to Martin Scorsesersquos Goodfellas. But even Goodfellas was based in reality - inspired by the non-fiction book, Wiseguy, about mobster-turned-informant, Henry Hill.Tony Soprano The late James Gandolfini memorably played New Jersey mob boss Tony on iconic TV show, The Sopranos. A new movie based on the young Tonys le stars Gandolfinis son, Michael, and will be released next spring.MAUREEN SUGDEN

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  Face it  the age of free movement is over as Covid leads to hard borders
story: Donald Trump closed the US borders yesterday to all immigrants in a tweet that was widely criticised as ldquoxenophobic and racist ndash an attempt to cover his own incompetence. Yet caring, sharing Jacinda Ardern has done exactly the same in New Zealand. No foreigners have been permitted to enter since the Antipodean country the lockdown.Nor is there any certainty that New Zealandrsquos borders are going to reopen any time soon. At the very least, future immigrants will have to put up with quarantine and long delaysthey are allowed into the country at all. Itrsquos a Brexiterrsquos wet dream.In Scotland, the Government is under pressure to explain why, as The Herald reported recently, , people have been allowed to enter the country apparently with barely any health checks at all. This seems to be a UK policy. Border controls are not devolved, and the UK Government seems to want to keep airports open for business.SNP MSPs and MPs are also talking about closing Scotlandrsquos border. MP Joanna Cherry has demanded, at the very least, rigorous health checks and quarantine at airports. Commentators, like our own Neil Mackay, are calling on Nicola Sturgeon to detach Scotland from the failing Westminster Government and introduce a rigorous independent policy of test, track and trace following Germanyrsquos lead.You only need to look at what is happening in Singapore to understand why voters are concerned about the UKrsquos laissez-faire approach to border security. This scrupulously tidy city state had been the poster child for Covid management. Thanks to its experience of SARS a decade ago it was well prepared.The lockdown was rapid and the country adopted mass testing and contact tracing from the start. By the beginning of April, Singapore seemed to be well on top of he disease. Then came the second wave.On Monday, Singapore recorded more than , new cases of Covid , its highest ever. The country of five million people now leads south-east Asia in the virulence of this disease.And who are they blaming  Well, the one million migrant workers, from countries like Bangladesh, who sweep the city streets and tend its butterfly gardens. The most virulent new outbreak is in their cramped dormitories.The Singapore authorities have quarantined thousands of migrant workers into what are to all intents and purposes Covid concentration camps. Eye witnesses report squalid conditions, rats and poor food.Now, New Zealand is one of the most liberal and open societies in the world. But it is going to allow migrants to enter the country freely any time soon  Is it going to allow the four million or so annual tourists  My daughter is one of them. Shersquos been in a Queenstown backpackers hostel under lockdown for the last month.The ethnic dimension to Covid is going to be a huge issue in the near future. Itrsquos already clear that BAME people are more prone to getting this disease. That may be genetic, or it may be to do with their social circumstances and over-crowding. But it means that, in authoritarian countries, they risk being singled out for epidemiological social cleansing.Covid is changing the world in dramatic and disturbing ways. We are seeing a big increase in economic nationalism. The European Union has been riven with tension over Germanyrsquos reluctance to share the Covid-related debts of Italy.Global companies are suffering billions in losses from the disruption of international trade and are repatriating supply chains. This re-shoring, as it is known, had already been happening before Covid, as wages have risen in China, making manufacturing there less attractive.Apple canrsquot market its new phones because of disruption to factories in China. It canrsquot rely on foreign sweatshop labour any more because the sweatshops are going to be transformed to combat the disease.But the pandemic has added yet another dimension to it. There is huge uncertainty about when andborders will relax. It is beginning to look aswe may have economic disruption until a vaccine is found, and even after that.This is why Mr Trumprsquos much-criticised travel ban makes a great deal of sense from his nationalistic, America First, politics. The Presidentrsquos Twitter rants seem arbitrary, contradictory, callous and unthinking. And they are. But they are also politically astute.The Democrats have got themselves into a mess by attacking Mr Trumprsquos border closures. They accused him of racism when he banned flights from the European Union back in February. And again today. But his voters only see him following the example of other countries.America is a vast country, with a erse economy providing most of what it needs from corn to cars. It could effectively shut the world out. Indeed, the US is arguably much better placed to do that than New Zealand because it can do without many of the imports other more open countries depend on.Here, SNP supporters argue that, since Scotlandrsquos death rate is currently running at around half of Englandrsquos, Ms Sturgeon should be following Jacinda Ardern and locking the border. There is immense frustration that Nicola Sturgeon appears to be dictated to by the UK Government.Health is devolved and the Scottish NHS could have pursued a dferent policy. However, as this column has repeatedly pointed out, the Scottish Government is following the same scientic advice as England. There is no evidence that Ms Sturgeon would have followed a dferent course had Scotland been independent.But social media is echoing to demands to lock foreigners out of Scotland for safetyrsquos sake. Ms Sturgeon is an internationalist and will never do that. But the resurgence of nationalism across the world is making borders ever more important to voters. Face up to it: the age of globalisation and free movement is over.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: international-aid-inspiring-pair
story: Ian Goldin, professor of globalisation and development at Oxford University, warned how Covid- was the biggest disaster for developing nations lsquoin our letime.rsquoFor some, like Uganda which only has  intensive care beds for a population of  million, it is unthinkable.ldquoNo poor country could afford the economic safety net that is currently sustaining citizens and companies here in the UK, he said. ldquoPoorer people are at greater risk of catching the virus and are more likely to suffer the worst effects of an economic shock.More than a third of all jobs and income in Africa could be lost, he said, with the vast majority of people living in countries in sub-Saharan Africa employed in the informal sector and receiving no unemployment, sickness or other benefits.ldquoThere is the question of how countries will cope with the coming medical emergency, he added. ldquoIn South Africa, for example, it is expected that the pandemic peak will only be reached in September, but incomes have already shrunk due to a lockdown that was announced before the UKrsquos and is every bit as stringent as that in Italy.He called for international support, which has been lacking, he said, as the US lsquoturns its back on the worldrsquo and the UK is too preoccupied with its own crisis.ldquoWe need a global Marshall plan that would write off of the bn in debt due by African countries in  and give at least .tn in aid to poor countries, he said ldquoIf there is one lesson Covid- has taught us, it is how interconnected our lives are. In the case of Covid-,one country is a pandemic hotspot, wersquore all at risk of reinfection.The ScotsmanScottish Labour leader Richard Leonard hoped the reconvening of the Scottish Parliament - obeying social distancing rules - would lsquousher in a new phase of heightened accountability and greater openness.rsquoHe said the national emergency was lsquoall the more reason for an intensication rather than a dilution of parliamentary scrutiny.rsquoldquoThat means members of the Scottish Parliament from all parties should have access to fully question Government ministers who are running the country during these most extraordinary of times, he said. ldquoEverywhere around there is mounting pressure to restart the economy. For me the choice is clear. Put simply, peoplersquos lives and well-being must be placed ahead of business considerations.He said those putting themselves most at risk during the pandemic - those working in care, for example, and stacking shelves supermarkets - are already those on lower wages, even zero hours contracts.ldquoSo the parliamentary scrutiny which we now need is about ensuring that the real-lived experiences of people have an influential bearing on the decisions made by both governments, he argued. ldquoIt is about ensuring that the maximum level of income support goes to those who need it. But it is also about the ethics of how we treat our elderly and infirm in the face of this pandemic. Everyone must have an equal right of access to treatment, dignity and respect and so the chance of le itself.The Stephen Pollard admitted there lsquowasnrsquot much to cheer about at the momentrsquo but, at a time when anyone over  is deemed especially vulnerable, he said, there was a lsquowonderful irony that the two people who have done most to bring us together are both in their s.rsquoldquoCaptain Tom Moore, the war veteran who captivated the nation over the weekend with his fund-raising walk for the NHS, is a scarcely believable , he said ldquoBut when it comes to the scarcely believable, nothing comes close to the fact that Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II is  today.Just over two weeks ago she spoke to the nation - and the world - about the pandemic.ldquoThere is no one  on the planet who could have talked as she did, with the history she has lived through and been part of, and with the respect she has earned from a le devoted to service and duty, he said. ldquoWe are so lucky to have her and all the more so at a time of national crisis.

title: letters-now-vital-government-goes-way
story: The UK did not start its present lockdown until March . Up until then, the UK Government had given out very mixed messages. It allowed international sports fixtures to go ahead, allowing , fans from virus-hit Madrid to come to watch Liverpool play on March . It allowed racingrsquos Cheltenham Festival to go ahead from March -. It stopped contact tracing on March  with no apparent strategy to replace it.Between March  and , the hospital death rates were doubling every two-to three days. On March , Boris Johnson gave a speech which advised people to socially distance and not go to pubs and restaurants. Schools remained open. Although a section of the community took this advice, public transport was still very crowded, people were still going out, and on the following weekend, we saw thousands of people flocking to beauty spots across the country. Obviously the message that Mr Johnson had given was not understood and did not have the intended effect and transmission was still occurring to a great extent.Finally, on March , the present lockdown was announced. If this had been done a week previously, as in Germany, Austria and other places, our death and infection rates would be up to a quarter of those at present. With a doubling rate of three days, simple mathematics shows that in a week, the infections will quadruple. If the present lockdown had been announced a week earlier, a lot of our present problems would not be as great. There would be less need for PPE, intensive care beds and mortuaries. The lockdown would not be required as long as the virus would not have infected as much of the community. The economy would perhaps be less affected.A few weeks ago Professor Jason Leitch was talking about achieving herd immunity in an interview on BBC Scotland. Todayit has been reported that the WHO estimates only two to three per cent of the population is infected. It has also been suggested that having had Covid- does not guarantee immunity. This should hopefully stop any suggestion that we should allow successive waves of infection until we build up herd immunity.The Scottish Government needs to organise testing in the community and contact tracing so that we can ease the lockdown and keep the virus under control. The suggestion that this could start off in the more easily-isolated areas of the country seems a good idea. The Scottish Government should not be waiting for a ided, leaderless UK Government Cabinet to make a decision.Rob Evans, Dundee DD.IT is vital that the Scottish Government follows the advice from Neil Mackay. Health issues are devolved to the Scottish Government andNicola Sturgeon is unable to draw up regulations appropriate for the conditions which pertain in Scotland then that does call into question how Scotland could operate as an independent country. The Scottish Government must show that it is capable of governing the country in a distinct and appropriate manner.The regulations in all four home countries appear to have been cut and pasted from the same source. As an initial response that was quite acceptable, especiallythe source document has originally come from the World Health Organisation or the regulations imposed in another European country. However, now that the regulations have been in force for a month the four home countries need to develop their own regulations. The lower population density in Scotland presents both opportunities and challenges. The easy option is to follow Boris Johnson and then claim a big boy did it and ran away.Sandy Gemmill, Edinburgh EH.NEIL Mackay has deemed Boris Johnsonrsquos approach to the coronavirus pandemic as a ldquodisaster and has urged Nicola Sturgeon to ldquobreak away. Ms Sturgeon has been at pains to stay more or less aligned to the Westminster approach, so far, which is to her credit, but deviation can only be sensiblethe course ahead is definite.All politicians will make mistakes over this new and uncharted coronavirus outbreak, it is inevitable, and sadly lives are always subject to such political judgments. At this stage no one can be sure about most of the answers but what is terribly obvious is that this whole episode has exposed the fragilities of Scottish independence. Just look at the oil price situation for example, hence Ms Sturgeonrsquos desire not to be out on a limb for fear of it breaking, and rightly so. It will not please some nationalists but we are definitely better together at this point in time and our First Minister seems to be aware of this fact.Dr Gerald Edwards, Glasgow G.IT is almost impossible to try to make sense of Neil Mackayrsquos article in a non-political perspective. First, no one can at this stage know what the result of the UK Government strategy will be. His criticism based on personalities is hardly factual. The main thrust of his argument that the Scottish Government should take a dferent approach is confusing, as there has been nothing to stop it doing so up to now presumably it believes the UKrsquos approach to be correct. Mr Mackay now needs to inform us in detail what detailed steps we should take in Scotland that are dferent.Colin McKay, Newton Stewart.THE UK Government has been on the receiving end of criticism from people and organisations across the political spectrum for its handling of some of the UK manestations of the Covid- pandemic.In particular, when the decision was announced in the last week or so in March, that the country would enter a period of lockdown which brought the economic le of the country to a juddering halt, there was comment that this action should have been taken seven,  or even more days earlier, and perhaps it should have. However, I wonderthe decision to postpone the onset of lockdown was made for very pragmatic reasons.Scroll back six or seven weeks or so, and we were being regaled on an almost daily basis in both print and broadcast media of y queues of people with trolleys waiting for supermarkets to open, and some time later, leaving these emporiums with trolleys stacked high with toilet rolls, kitchen paper, rice, pasta, part-baked bread rolls and other non-perishable goods, stripping the shelves bare in the process.Despite repeated pleas from civic, political and religious leaders, and the supermarket chains themselves, this activity continued for many days. I would imagine that, when introducing a new policy, particularly one which imposes considerable new restrictions, ministers and their advisors would consider what would be the likelihood of the target population co-operating with these new impositions, andimprobable, what scale of resources and expenditure would be required to compel and maintain their compliance.Given the response to the appeal for shoppers to revert to the pattern of purchasing that they had found perfectly adequate in the last week of January, the Government probably felt that it would have little chance of persuading the general population to accept much more drastic restrictions, at least until it had been persistently exposed to the carnage taking place in Italy and Spain. Even then, there were a signicant number of so-called Covidiots who seemed intent on defying any attempt to curb their liberty.Christopher W Ide, Waterfoot.THE language of war and battles to fight the coronavirus must stop.Language is a powerful tool. It can be used to both praise and demonise but either way it has an effect of on people, their wellbeing, their mental health. However, just as important as the adverse or positive effect that language can have on us as iniduals, words are also capable of shaping the public narrative to convince us what to think. Using war language to fight a health crisis is not helpful for at least three main reasons.The first is that it undermines legitimate challenge which, when it is absent, encourages systemic negligence to run rampantly unchecked.Secondly, it lulls us to uncritically accept the inevitability of thousands upon thousands of deaths, especially enabling the expendability of the costly, most vulnerable people in our society.Thirdly, war language demands sacrice and a culture of silence. This expectation is unnecessary, unwanted, and unhelpful it is anti-democratic and smacks of political expediency.All of these impacts are worrying and serves only as power and compliance tools for our political governors. Frontliners are workers, consistently undervalued ones, granted, but they are not warriors and they deserve the best protection. In light of this, more, many more questions need to be asked and answered.Why were we not prepared for this  Why are so many people dying compared to countries like Germany  Why are so many people dying in our care homes  Why are we demanding that our friends and family work on the frontline without full and proper protection for themselves and their patients  Why is there no urgency or recognition of the need to test and track Finally, in this modern Scotland, is it too much to ask to be treated like adults and receive honest answers in this bumbling, post-truth political world Councillor Brian McGinley , Ayr.I AM one of those people who go out every Thursday at pm to say thank you to all those dedicated people who are putting their lives and those of their families at risk to save others. I am, however, disappointed that the only references made regarding the Police Service are of issuing fines and heavy-handed tactics in dealing with the public in these dficult times.Their job is dficult enough and there is always a fine balance between discretion and enforcement. So on Thursday I will be including the police in my tribute to the emergency services.Neil Stewart, Balfron.News from trusted and credible sources is essential at all times, but especially now as the coronavirus pandemic impacts on all aspects of our lives. title: paper-boat-artists-prints-go-sale-world-earth-day
story: George Wylliersquos ambitious public art achieved international acclaim and attention, with the Straw Locomotive hanging from the Finnieston Crane for six weeks before being set alight, and his Paper Boat sculpture sailing from the Clyde to New Yorkrsquos Hudson River.The artist, who died in  at the age of , used his work to raise awareness of the industrial demise of his home town of Glasgow, as well as to highlight environmental issues.And now ndash to mark the th anniversary of Earth Day ndash one of his pieces will be sold on special release to help raise money for a Scottish environmental charity.Prints of Mr Wylliersquos Original Earth Guarantee from his multi-award winning play, A Day Down a Goldmine, are being sold by his family, with a donation going to Keep Scotland Beautul.Mr Wylliersquos eldest daughter, Louise Wyllie, said: ldquoMy father was always concerned about the way in which the Earth was at risk from climate change brought about by humanity. It was a key driver behind a lot of his late work in particular.ldquoDad was always ahead of his time and this particular piece of work resonates now, more than ever. He would have been delighted that young people are leading the campaign to preserve the planet. The Original Earth Guarantee stresses the Earth has been  made from the best materials available . It s our duty to look after it. Every household should have an Original Earth Guarantee as a reminder. The print, which outlines a contract guaranteeing the Earth, is stamped with Mr Wylliersquos playful nature and mimics an official legal document while setting out a number of dire warnings about the future of the planet.The last line reads: ldquoIf the terms of this Guarantee are not complied with, a WARNING is hereby given that the Guarantee, AND the product known as Earth, will be rendered VOID.Mr Wyllie became a full-time artists later in le in his late-s after serving as a sailor in the Royal Navy and as a ustoms and excise officer in Inverclyde for  years. Best-known for the Straw Locomotive in  and the Paper Boat in , his other artistic pieces include The Running Clock outside Glasgowrsquos Buchanan Bus Station and the Monument to Maternity, a huge nappy pin on the site of the cityrsquos former Rottenrow Maternity Hospital.Born in Glasgow in , he continued making art at his home overlooking the Firth of Clyde in Gourock until he was in his eighties.

title: brian-beacom-never-thought-say-thank-goodness-piers-morgan
story: And therersquos the controversy: publishing fake pictures at the Mirror of British troops abusing Iraqi captives, the allegations of insider trading, his ldquosychophantic" ndash said  per cent of Radio Times viewers ndash interview with Donald Trump in .Itrsquos not to hard to see why Jeremy Clarkson, at the  Press Awards, delivered three rapid blows in the direction of Morganrsquos barsquo face.Yet, we need this self-confessed ldquorampant egomaniac because Morgan has become a Covid- champion for the truth and transparency that Westminster and Holyrood have failed to deliver.Just look at his backstory in recent months. The Good Morning Britain host was trashed for his criticism of Professor Jason Leitch, when the National Clinical Directorrefused to accept mass quarantining was the answer. ldquoListen to the expert! yelled Professor Leitch.Well, we did, and then we heard him say: ldquoWe have absolutely adequate levels of testing in Scotland. We heard his arguments for not testing: ldquoWersquore having to delay the spread of the virus. And, unbelievably, we heard him argue against social distancing: ldquoYou canrsquot keep m people six feet apart.We needed Morganrsquos questions at the time and we needed him again to kick hard at the shins of his Good Morning Britain colleague Dr Hilary after the telly doc backed the UK Governmentrsquos case for not yet closing the schools. Morgan raged again at the Government line, attacking Cabinet Minister Simon Clarke over "shameful" handling of PPE and him ldquonot having a clue how many health care staff had died. And during an interview with English culture secretary Oliver Dowden, Morganrsquos blood boiled at the insanity of allowing the Cheltenham Festival and the Liverpool v Atletico Madrid match to go ahead.But Morgan has shown added value this week on CNN, lambasting the morally bankrupt flibbertigibbet that is Boris Johnson and the asinine Donald Trump. . ldquoIrsquove been watching these daily briefings with mounting horror and, at almost every level, Donald Trump is failing the American people, with his self-aggrandising, self-justying rants.Morgan added: ldquoTo him, itrsquos more important he win the election in November. But it should be about focusing on saving human le. Trumprsquos following, thankfully, has dropped six points.Now, Morgan isnrsquot clairvoyant and he certainly doesnrsquot always get the argument right.This week he attacked Dr Andrew Lilico, after the economist had criticised the NHS, leaping onto easy argument like John Wayne on a small horse, off to kill some Injuns. But Dr Lilicorsquos argument about "NHS worship" was certainly not a criticism of those brave enough to work for this underfunded service.But what Piers Morgan at least managed was to open the debate. And almost daily he reminds us debate has been largely shut down. Our own First Minsterrsquos daily briefing, for example, doesnrsquot allow for a second question, allowing the opportunity to obfuscate, take a thick black bingo marker to the unanswered question.This weekend, English Education Secretary Gavin Williamson told us is was our ldquocivic duty to persist with the lockdown. And hersquos absolutely on the money. But isnrsquot it also our civic duty to ask questions of our leaders, to question our command and control style of government Thatrsquos why we need journalists with a very loud voice, to ask why wersquore allowing , people a day to fly into the UK  Or to demand to know why we didnrsquot learn from the Italian tragedy and not lock down earlier.Donrsquot we all want to know why Scotland initially chose a dferent Covid- strategy to Westminster, only for our FM and the PM to tie their ankles together in a bizarre three-legged race ndash and run in the wrong direction ndash while Angela Merkel was heading for the finishing line Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: revealed-uk-airports-biggest-drop-traffic-since-lockdown-started
story: Since thelockdown was announced on March , ordinary le has come to a standstill and a dramatic number of flights have been grounded.The UK Government recently requested that any Britishnationals still abroad for business or short-term purposeshome immediately.The Foreign and Commonwealth Officehas since advised Brits against all but absolutely essential travel worldwide, with restrictions applying for an indefinite period.Many countries around the world have now closed their borders to foreigners and may restrict travel without any notice.As a result of these unprecedented measures, flight traffic in the UK has been in sharp decline since the lockdown was first announced - with some airports seeing a reduction of  per cent.These are the airports that have seen the biggest weekly reduction in flights, according to data from flightradar:The data looks at the drop in weekly flights between the week ending March and the week ending April .Cardf, Leeds Bradford Airport and Newquay recorded no flights at all in the week ending April , representing a drop of  per cent.Gatwick, which saw  flights in the week ending March , saw just  flights take off in the week ending April .Lockdown measures around the world have seen air and motor traffic fall dramatically, leading to a reduction in air pollution in many cities.Some cities have seen nitrogen dioxidelevels fall by up to  per cent since last year, analysis shows.Environmental campaigners hope that the drop will encourage permanent action on pollution even when lockdown measures are eased.Scientists are also exploring a possible link between the severity of air pollution and the chances of dying from coronavirus.However, medical scientists say it is still too early to confirm a definite link between the severity of Covid- and pollution in areas where patients live.

title: yousaf-says-given-up-leonard-scottish-labour-islamophobia
story: The Justice Secretary said the Scottish Labour leader had ldquono credibility on the issuegiven at least one high-profile investigation had now dragged on more than two years.Mr Yousaf told BBC Radio Scotland: ldquoI have to say Irsquove given up even speaking to Richard Leonard on this matter.In March , Labour suspended Dumfries  Galloway councillor Jim Dempster after he made an Islamophobic comment about Mr Yousaf, who was then SNP transport minister.Cllr Dempster had referred to Mr Yousaf being invisible ldquounder his burka.Mr Leonard said at the time Cllr Dempster that had ldquounreservedly apologised for the hurt and offence caused, and there would be ldquoan inquiry and a due process will be followed.However, despite Cllr Dempster admitting the remark, Labour has still to conclude its inquiry.Asked about the case, Mr Yousaf told Good Morning Scotland he had no faith in Scottish Labour to act and urged new UK leader Sir Keir Starmer to settle the matter.He said: ldquoRichard Leonard has no credibility on this issue any more. I would urge Keir Starmer, the new leader of the Labour party in the UK, to process these complaints, to take decisive action, not just against Councillor Jim Dempster, but many others.He went on: ldquoIn terms of Richard Leonard,he thinks hersquos done enough and can now just pass over responsibility, and duck responsibility, then he should at the very least release all the correspondence that he sent to the UK Labour party on this issue demanding action is being action, so that we can actually judge the fact hersquos made an effort.ldquoI have to say Irsquove given up even speaking to Richard Leonard on this matter, or indeed raising it with the Scottish Labour party, because itrsquos clear to me that they donrsquot take these matters at all seriously.Earlier on the same show, Mr Leonard was asked about Mr Yousafrsquos previously saying he should be ashamed to show his face at anti-racism rallies given the Dempster case delay.Mr Leonard said: ldquoI am always happy to speak to Humza Yousaf about where we are with this case. I am frustrated as well that itrsquos taken as long as it has.ldquoItrsquos not clear to me why it has taken as long as it has.ldquoHe has been suspended and does not play an active part in the Labour party or the Labour group where hersquos an elected councillor.Pressed on a timetable for resolving the case, Mr Leonard said: ldquoIt needs to be resolved, in my view, timeously. Look, for the le of me I donrsquot know why it has taken as long as it has.ldquoIt ought to have been dealt with more speedily, but the consideration of that case rests in the hands of the party at a UK level.Mr Leonard then tried to change the focus of the interview back to coronavirus.He said: ldquoI have to say, some of these issues are a source of frustration to me, but in the end we are dealing with a national crisis where people are dying, and the effect of this pandemic ought to be the thing which is first and foremost in our discussions and debates.ldquoItrsquos whatrsquos driving me, itrsquos what Irsquom spending all my waking hours dealing with, not with some of the internal grievance and disciplinary procedures of the Labour party.Mr Leonard was also asked about readmitting nine Labour councillors who were suspended from the party in May  for working with the Tories on Aberdeen City Council.Mr Leonardrsquos new deputy, Dumbarton MSP Jackie Baillie, and the Shadow Scottish Secretary Ian Murray have both called for the lsquoAberdeen Ninersquo to be let back into the party.Asked why the matter had gone on for years and whether he was minded to readmit them, Mr Leonard again deferred to Labour in London: ldquoThe case of the Aberdeen councillors rests with the national constitutional committee of the Labour party.ldquoThere is a due process which needs to be followed and I am frustrated that it has taken as long as it has, but there is a due process which needs to be followed.ldquoTheir case is resting with the national constitutional committee of the Labour party.Askedthe committee was fit for purpose given the delay, Mr Leonard said: ldquoI am also frustrated it has taken as long as it has to get this resolved.ldquoWe understand that there is frustration faced by people in the Labour party in Aberdeen, members of that group in Aberdeen, but also this has wider implications too about how we go about our business as a party and itrsquos important that we give due process and donrsquot prejudice the hearings that will take place at some point in the future.In November, Mr Leonard admitted it was ldquoentirely unsatisfactory the case had taken so long, but refused to get involved, saying it was a matter for Labourrsquos national constitutional committee.Askedhe ought to be involved, he said: ldquoNo, I donrsquot think I should be. I think itrsquos right therersquos a separation between the political leadership of the party and political representatives of the party and those people who are directly elected to carry out those investigations.It prompted Mr Yousaf at the time to accuse Mr Leonard of a ldquocomplete lack of leadership.

title: coronavirus-scotland-forgotten-construction-industry-calls-support
story: TheScottish Building Federationsaid a survey of its members revealedmore than three-quarters have seen all cash flow stop, whilst  per cent have furloughed at least % of their staff.Despite this, the industry ndashwhich employs over , people and makes up a substantial slice of the economy ndash says it has receivedno specic support.Official analysis has warned Scotlands economy could shrink by a third during the coronavirus lockdown, with the potential for ldquolong lasting impacts.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Care home deaths almost equal those in hospitalsVaughan Hart, managing director of SBF, said most of its members have heeded advice to stop working to protectstaff and the wider community.He said: ldquoWe welcome the Scottish Governmentrsquos second phase of funding which includes a fund of poundm to support businesses in financial distress due to Covid-.ldquoOther heavily-impacted sectors which were initially advised to close have rightly received signicant support and other industries have now received bespoke support packages from the Scottish Government. "Construction seems to have been forgotten despite being one of the most crucial sectors to the Scottish economy."Our sector employs over , people and is % of the Scottish economy but many of our members are struggling. "They urgently need specic support from governmentthey are to survive the current crisis and be in a position to help rebuild the Scottish economy when it ends.:Coronavirus: Charity demands action as Scottish care home deaths more than double in a weekThe SBF said the retail, hospitality and leisure sectors have been designated ldquoheavily-impacted and benefit from % rates relief as well as further grant funding.Its survey of more than  members indicated that only % of construction firms are eligible for the pound, grant funding offered through the Small Business Bonus Schemeand Rural Rate Relief .It found cashflowhas stopped entirely at % of firms, while% want similar support to that offered to retail, hospitality and leisure businesses.The vast majorityof sites controlled by SBF members are closed in compliance with the guidance issued by the Scottish Government, with the remainder falling under the lsquoessential workrsquo category.Elsewhere, figures showretail sales have plummeted by % in the last two weeks of March .

title: keir-starmer-accuses-uk-govt-repeatedly-slow-response-pandemic-first-digital-pmqs
story: The new Labour leader and Foreign Secretary Mr Raab - deputising for Boris Johnson as the Prime Minister continued his recovery from Covid- - faced each other in a sparsely attended House of Commons as the majority of MPs participated remotely.Sir Keir questioned the Governments progress towards its target of carrying out , tests a day by the end of the month and claimed that opportunities to acquire personal protective equipment [PPE] from British firms had been missed.He said: "There is a pattern emerging here. We were slow into lockdown, slow on testing, slow on protective equipment and now slow to take up these offers from British firms.":Coronavirus in Scotland: Hospital death toll breaches , as , dischargedMr Raab told him that the Government was guided by scientic advisers.He said thatSir Keir "thinks he knows better than they do, with the benefit of hindsight, then thats his decision".Mr Raab said , British businesses had responded to a call for assistance on PPE and they had all received a response, with some , followed up where it was "sensible"they had equipment with the required specication and volume.He said it was an "incredibly dficult and competitive international environment" to source PPE from overseas.On testing, the latest figures showed that less than half of the available capacity was being used and fewer than , tests had been carried out in a -hour period.Sir Keir questioned how the Government would ramp that up to , tests a day in just eight days time - particularly as some care workers and NHS staff could only be testedthey could drive to a site.UK ministers have repeatedly insisted the target will be met and Mr Raab insisted that "those tests will be crucial not just in terms of controlling the virus but allowing the country to move to the next phase".:Coronavirus: Charity demands action as Scottish care home deaths more than double in a weekHe said mobile labs were now being used with the Army also helping to get tests to where they were needed.Mr Raab told MPs Mr Johnson continued to recover from coronavirus at Chequers and was in "good spirits".In other developments -*An RAF plane landed at Brize Norton from Turkey in the early hours of Wednesday, after being sent to collect a shipment of PPE - including badly-needed surgical gown.*The Government continued to face questions about its participation in EU schemes to secure vital equipment with Brussels saying there had been "ample opportunity" for the UK to join in.*More than  frontline NHS staff were confirmed to have died during the coronavirus pandemic*Professor Robin Shattock from Imperial Colleges Department of Infectious Disease, said a coronavirus vaccine may be available for front-line workers and the most vulnerable by late winter*Cancer Research UK warned that more than , new cancer cases could be going undetected each week as fewer people go to see their GP and also due to practitioners reluctance to send patients to hospital due to the risk of Covid- infection.*Labour said  companies had approached them to claim that offers of help to supply PPE had been ignored. They included Issa Exchange Ltd in Birmingham which said it offered a quarter of a million aprons and masks, Network Medical Products in Ripon, which says it can provide , face visors per week and CQM Learning, which says it can provide , face shields per day.

title: coronavirus-uk-at-peak-covid-19
story: Speaking in the House of Commons this afternoon Matt Hancock said the country had now reached the peak of the disease, but said there would not be changes to the current lockdown strategy.He also confirmed that  social care staff have died having contracted Covid- while working in nursing homes and care settings.Mr Hancock told MPs that five things had to be achieved "before we relax any social distancing rules or make changes", including ensuring the NHS is able to cope, and continuing to see the daily number of people who de from the virus falling "consistently".He said: "We are at the peak. But before we relax any social distancing rules, or make changes to that we have set out five tasks that have to be met. First that the NHS can continue to cope second that the operational challenges have been met third, that the daily death rate falls sustainably and consistently fourth that the rate of infection is decreasing, and most importantly fth, that there is no risk of a second peak."The minister said that while the government is still working towards its UK-wide goal of carrying out , tests a day by the end of the month, he admitted that "demand has thus far been lower than expected" although the "expansion of capacity is ahead of plan".The Government is now expected to increase the categories of workers eligible to be tested in an attempt to meet its goal, as well as increase the number of mobile testing units available and send out at-home testing kits for those unable to reach testing sites.It has been suggested that supermarket workers could be among those offered testing.Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth demanded that staff be given testing "at a local NHS site or by mobile unit, as it is clearly ludicrous to expect care workers to travel miles to drive-thru test centres."Former labour leader Jeremy Corbyn also said the government was "nowhere near" the level of testing needed.Mr Hancock responded: "We were one of the first countries in the world to develop a test, we rapidly increase the number of tests from  at the start of March to , thats a multiple of five times during March, and now going up further. This is an area where weve had our foot on the gas, all the way through."Meanwhile the Scottish Conservatives have urged the Scottish Government to take the lead on mobile testing, particularly in remote areas.
